I do!
My boobs are super fibrous so they really don't need a ton of support and I tend to wear loose tops so usually just wear a cami with a shelf or a bralette unless I'm working out or wearing something where it would be obvious if I tried to freeboob.

A very similar thing happened to my sister who has GI problems.
It sucked for her to have to convince people that she had a legitimate physical problem, but I can't blame the doctors for suspecting an eating disorder when they saw a 17 year old girl with an anorexic sister who was rapidly losing a ton of weight due to GI problems that did not seem to resolve with medication.
It isn't uncommon for people with GI disorders to develop eating disorders because restricting their food intake feels like a way to "control" their illness, and food can be a major source of anxiety when it may or may not make you feel super sick.

Eh, I'm working on it I guess. Right now I'm in college and in a stable, healthy relationship with an awesome dude. I still suck at eating and struggle a lot but the rest of my life is going pretty well and I my depression and anxiety are managed much better these days.

A lot of different staff wear scrubs and it can vary based on your hospital and the setting that a specific person works in but in a hospital most patient transporters, scribes, techs (EKG, rad, ER, diet etc.), medical assistants, unit clerks, nursing assistants/CNAs/STNAs/caregivers, patient sitters/safety companions, pharmacy technicians, phlebotomists and respiratory therapists/techs will be wearing scrubs.
Nursing itself is a pretty big field; practical/vocational nurses have a certificate about 18 months of training where RNs have at least an associates degree (which is a 2 year nursing program plus however long it takes you to complete all of the science prerequisites). I'm currently in school studying for a bachelors degree in nursing, when I graduate I will sit for boards and assuming I pass I will be an RN.

I mean a lot of people wear scrubs besides doctors and nurses (sorry, as a nursing student it is one of my pet peeves that people assume any non doctor wearing scrubs is a nurse)
A lot of hospitals are banning smoking, like they will not hire you if you smoke and if it is found out that you smoke you can be fired.
I'm a biracial pharma brat so whenever someone asks where I'm from I'm always tempted to give them a rundown of all of the places my family relocated to when I was a kid.

I know that I could get a similar product for cheaper but I'm willing to pay a premium for a product that syncs up with my other devices and is user friendly enough that I can just boot it up and start using it right out of the box.

Honestly, most of my meals are pretty depressing. I have an eating disorder (anorexia binge/purge subtype) so I mostly eat alone and my meals are whatever will give me the most volume for the least calories.
I think the most depressing is when I binge and purge, or even just when I purge. I remember one time when I was in high school my mom made me eat lunch before I went out and I ended up making myself throw up into an empty gallon ziplock bag in my car because I couldn't make myself keep down that tuna sandwich.
Bingeing is sad because it starts off innocent but once I have what I see as "too much" or a bite of a "forbidden" food my brain just goes into fuck it mode and I have uncontrollable urges to shove anything that I wouldn't normally let myself eat into my facehole since the day is already ruined. Its sad because at this point I kind of enjoy it, I have a system and routines and sometimes I even plan my b/p sessions.

My birth plan: I want to survive this and a health baby as quickly and painlessly as possible, do whatever you think is appropriate to make that happen. If possible make sure that my vagina and anus remain separate holes.

I'm tall and thin (172 cm) and a lot of clothing is still too big for me so I can't even imagine how hard it is for legitimately tiny people.
I do like that I can save money by getting kids jackets and athletic shorts though.
And, if you have a freezer frozen vegetables are super cheap and you can stock up when they are on sale.
Their iced coffee is crap too, ITS SO WATERY IT LOOKS LIKE ICED TEA
I used to take a lot of "showers" because they were a good excuse for me to spend a lot of time in the bathroom and the running water covered up the sound of me making myself throw up.
Same thing in healthcare, especially now that patient satisfaction is tied to reimbursement.
Not to mention the racist undertones that all black men are "Mandingo's" who want to fuck anything with a pulse.

Same here!
I will probably work as an RN for several years but if/when I decide to pursue a higher degree I want to go to PA school.

People really don't seem to understand what a nurse even does. I wanted to be a doctor until I was hospitalized and realized that most of the things that attracted me to medicine were actually nursing tasks.
To the general public, anyone wearing scrubs who doesn't identify themselves as a doctor is a nurse.

(when someone is so backed up you have to double glove, lube up and stick your fingers up their rear to break up the blockage and bring it out)

That was my mom's deal, she called it a "good manners bite". I had to try everything but if I wanted to get myself an alternative (raw carrots instead of a cooked vegetable, rinsing sauce off of chicken) I could.
I'm still a picky eater, but I'm not afraid of trying new things because I learned from an early age that one bite of something I don't like isn't a big deal.

Ugh ugh UGH
This makes me so mad because in my opinion, the YMCA is one of the most body positive organizations out there! I may be biased because I work there as a camp counselor but their entire mission is based around helping people of all ages and abilities find ways to stay healthy and active members of their communities. They provide scholarships and financial assistance to lower income families so they they can have memberships and send their kids to camps and swimming lessons, they have fitness classes ranging from Advanced TRX to gentle yoga and water aerobics and specialized classes for people with Parkinson's disease. My branch employs a lot of young adults with intellectual disabilities to help them get work experience and become integrated into the community; they also have programs to help teach people with disabilities how to adapt exercises to their abilities.
I regularly see people of all ages and abilities interacting and encouraging each other to live healthier lives so it pisses me off to see someone trash the Y.
Making myself throw up.

I'm in a similar place right now.
I'm studying to be a nurse, I know how dangerous it is to restrict and purge but I can't stop.

Yeah thats pretty much my perspective.
I have an eating disorder and while having calorie counts will be a challenge that is a 'me' problem because I am a grown up and my mental health is my job.
Obviously people should try to be considerate of the needs of others but at a certain point we all need to learn to deal with our ish because we can't avoid it forever.

Yeah I have friends who are young, thin and exercise a lot who comment on how I walk almost everywhere (I live in a city and gas ain't cheap) and take the stairs like it is some sort of impressive physical feat.

I have friends who go to the gym almost every day and have no problem with an intentional 5 mile run but think that it is weird that I always take the stairs down (I live on the 10th floor of my building so I do sometimes use the elevator to go up if I'm carrying stuff) and walk places whenever possible.
It is so odd to me; it isn't like they are in any way opposed to exercise or incapable of covering the distances that I do.
Plus, a lot of black Americans don't really identify as African because their families have been in America since before 1807, when it became illegal to import slaves.
What do you think that we should call people?

Exactly! TYPE 2 DIABETES IS RELATIVELY EASY TO MANAGE IF YOU DON'T LET IT GET OUT OF CONTROL!
My grandmother is in her mid 70's and has had T2DM for at least 10 years but her blood sugar is still well controlled with oral meds despite her remarkably sedentary lifestyle because she keeps her weight down and watches her carb intake.
She still eats what she wants, she just makes trade offs through out the day to compensate. Last night she had a whole bunch of mashed potatoes with dinner, but she skipped out on dessert and took home some cookies and a slice of pie to have as an afternoon treat the next day.

I'm recovering from an eating disorder (anorexia with purging and compulsive exercise) so all of these goals are dependent on me treating my body right as right now I am underweight (according to my doctor, I have no interest in knowing the actual number as I still have trouble accepting that I should gain weight).
Get doctor's approval to start exercising again (I do it anyway but I would like to be a more compliant patient this year)
Run a 10K with the boyfriend
Commit to taking at least 2 technique classes and 1 pointe every week of the spring semester
Stop making myself throw up
Get over my weird fear of eating after exercise (and just eating in general)
I love that show but I really didn't want Michael to get a happy ending. I enjoyed watching the character but I wanted him to have to face his incompetence in the end.

I really don't want to support anything that Lena Dunham does, but a friend convinced me to watch an episode of Girls with her recently and what bothered me was how realistically shitty the characters are; it's just a show that portrays the annoying obnoxious people I have to deal with in my day to day life.

Exactly.
There is a huge difference between a show about a black female doctor and a show about a female doctor who happens to be played by a black actor.

Being skinny is something that I could be good at. I was a weird, awkward kid; I couldn't be pretty or charismatic like the popular girls but I could be skinny and skinny is ALL that I had to be. I grew up feeling very big and noticeable; while I was never overweight (looking back I was a super thin kid) I grew up in southern California and went to a school where most of the other kids were of Asian or Hispanic decent so I always towered over my peers.
I'm also just scared of gaining weight which is probably the biggest reason I struggle to recover. I have theories as to how this fear came about but I noticed that all of my relapses were triggered by me unintentionally losing a chunk of weight then refusing to regain it.

I really need to get my shit together before this eating disorder kills me. It's weird, most of the time I feel like I don't have a problem and everyone is crazy but every once in a while I will start panicking when I realize that after 8 years of eating disorder my body will only take so much.
I'm home for Christmas break so I won't see my treatment team until I go back to school in January so I have no idea what my weight is doing but my symptom use and disordered thought patterns are concerning to me. I really let my eating backslide during finals and I haven't been able to get myself back on track; on a good day I get in and keep down 2 restrictive meals and then I usually end up subjectively bingeing and purging in the evening. I feel like a "bad anorexic" because of the junk I eat and then purge so its easy for me to justify restricting since it clearly isn't an actual problem /s.
My family has a lot to deal with right now (my sister was the victim of a sexual assault and isn't coping well) so I really don't want to add on to their stress and guilt (my mom has already expressed that she feels like she failed us which is such BS because she is truly the best and most supportive parent a person could ask for).
So much in my life is going well right now; I made the Deans list despite what a mess I was when I took my finals, my boyfriend and I are still happily in love and I got into a really competitive clinical rotation for next semester but I can't seem to make myself eat like a normal person.
They are sometimes on sale at Kroger and I always panic and buy way too many.
That's amazing, I am so happy for you and wish you the best in your recovery.
I honestly can't really remember my "before" which makes the idea of recovery even scarier because I don't know what it would be like to live without an eating disorder.

I have anorexia, ADHD, celiac disease, depression and anxiety.
I am just tired of hearing people's "opinions" on whether or not these issues are real and how they think I should treat them. The fact is, I am not functioning well and however you choose to label things it is a problem and I need help.
Also the number of people who have told me that veganism will help with my eating disorder is astounding. I'll listen to the physicians and registered dieticians, thanks.
This one is the worst.

I always thought of musical theatre dance as its own thing; most MT kids are trained in at least ballet and jazz so the choreo in shows tends to combine a lot of elements.

Yeah, people aren't going to think someone in ill fitting clothes with a grim outlook on life looks that good.
I have a friend who is in the process of losing weight but even at her heaviest she has always looked great because she dresses in a way that flatters her body, and she SMILES and is energetic and bubbly!
This girl is 5 foot nothing and doesn't have the best distribution of her weight (plus when you're that short there are only so many places it can go) but she still got hit on and complimented because she is charismatic and knows how to work with what she has.

I think its even funnier when they learn that you can get better at things with practice but still haven't figured out that some things are just straight up impossible no matter how many times you try.

If it makes you feel better, a lot of hospitals used text messaging based alert systems instead of pagers so he may have responding to questions from nurses/colleagues.
No matter what it is still rude.
Same here!

As a former 13 year old who ended up in a mental hospital I just want to let you know that you did the right thing and as scary as this is your situation is not unusual or a result of anything that you did wrong 3

I agree. As a 19 year old college sophomore, the idea of dating a 16 year old icks me out; not because of the actual chronological age gap but because we would be in such different stages of life. I think that it would be hard to have an equal relationship when I'm an adult who lives on my own dating someone who is in high school and may not even have a drivers license.
It also seems weird from a social standpoint; I wouldn't want to hang out with a group of high schoolers and I would feel weird bringing a 16 year old to hang out with my friends (and I don't know if their parents would be into the idea of their minor child hanging out with a bunch of 19-23 year olds in a crappy apartment somewhere). I would worry that the relationship would become isolating.
It's basically the '50 Shades of Grey' of religious texts.

That's why my mom wouldn't let me get my ears pierced until I was 10. It annoyed me at the time but looking back it was fair; she didn't want to create extra work for herself for something that serves no real purpose.

Then you need black and tan LaDucas and god forbid you have t-straps when the costumer wants Mary Jane's.
Not to mention pointe shoes. I usually hate my flat feet but at least my shoes last longer, some of my super high arched friends need a new pair every week or 2 just from taking class.
I am very glad that I am the size of a large child and can get gently used stuff from rich people whose kids have gone through growth spurts.

It's crazy.
I know a girl who has 2 crazy expensive horses (1 hunter, 1 jumper) and they just look like they cost more than my college tuition.
The girl is super sweet and hardworking (she's from a horse family, not a spoiled brat who wanted a pony) but I can't imagine riding a horse that costs more than my car. Heck, I get nervous petting them.
I miss the days of barn shows where my lesson helmet with a velvet cover over it was good enough.
Yeah I live near KY and you can get "good but not up to crazy elite standards" for super cheap.

I'm a nursing major in a really well regarded/competitive program and while it is challenging, the actual material is no harder than the material you cover in any other science major. the challenge comes from the sheer volume and the time consuming nature of clinicals.
Nursing is hard but completely doable if you are reasonably intelligent, work hard and have decent time management.

I'm really glad my school doesn't let this shit fly.
We had an entire lecture our first year about how we are educated professionals doing a job that we are fairly compensated; acting like a martyr is unacceptable and just undermines your credibility as a member of the healthcare team.

Not to mention, good parents plan ahead and don't put their kids in situations that they won't be able to cope with or try to do the grocery shopping around nap or snack time when the kid will be tired or hungry.
Yup. Parents need to be realistic about what their kids can handle and not put them in situations that they don't have the skills to cope with.

Exactly.
I'm recovering from anorexia and while I generally look ok I'm still 10-15 pounds underweight and depending on the day may need to sit because I have low blood pressure and my blood sugar is unstable and will get really low if I'm not careful. I feel bad taking up a seat but I'd rather sit and have people think I'm lazy that run the risk of fainting which would ultimately be much more inconvenient for my fellow passengers.
Heck, even generally healthy people have shitty days; for all I know the fit looking dude sitting down has a killer ear infection and can't balance for shit or just got off a 36 hour on call shift where his pager never stopped beeping.
Well, the raging eating disorder and stress induced IBS keep the weight off pretty well.
You're like an ber minority.

Same here.
I mean it is challenging and time consuming but so is any other bachelor of science degree once you get past the 100 level classes.
I am in no way qualified but I would love to help!

I mean, as a 19 year old the idea of being with a 14 year old icks me out even though I am sure there are plenty of people in that age range who I would get along with and relate to socially.
We are just in completely different places in life to the point that it couldn't be a balanced relationship.
Spinach, 1/2 of an avocado, chicken breast and balsamic vinaigrette.
That's why you use rice instead of bread!
One time my uncle ate a super heavy, greasy lunch before donating plasma and he clogged the machine.

In my program you fail if your grade in the class or your test average is below 73% (so people can't pass on project grades). We have the second highest NCLEX pass rate in the state so I guess it is working.
Yeah I dress like an oversized toddler: t-shirt dresses, leggings, a giant sweater and sensible shoes ftw

I do ok with pants and I only wear long (at least knee length) skirts and dresses because I can't make myself sit like a grownup, but I can never find a decent pair of shorts.
I just want to be covered to my mid thighs, is that too much to ask?

It seems like most clothes are designed for people in the 5'5"-5'7" range. My mom is about 5'6" and pants are almost always the right length for her which makes me crazy jealous because I'm 5'8" so most pants are just a tiny bit too short for me, but if I get pants made for tall people they are way too long.

My mom had me in a booster until I was in 4th or 5th grade (I remember because it made me so mad that I was the only one of my friends that still had to use one).
I'm currently college aged (so I grew up in the late 90's/early 2000's) and I wasn't tiny but my mom always did things by the book so I used a booster until I hit 4'9'' (I was a skinny kid so if we waited until I hit 85 pounds I would have been sitting in that thing until middle school).

Anorexic student nurse here!
Honestly, you can't do any job well with an active eating disorder once you have reached a certain point; no matter what you want to do you need to get yourself into treatment and commit to recovery before you end up with permanent medical problems that could make it more difficult for you to have the career that you want.
I had a pretty bad relapse and I'm struggling right now and while I'm still doing well in school I know that this would be a heck of a lot easier if I wasn't in the throes of an eating disorder.

The state of NP education is making me really nervous. I'm not even halfway through my undergrad but as it stands I can't see myself wanting to become an NP because even if I graduate from a rigorous program and have years of experience under my belt, I will have the same title and degree as people who skated through an online diploma mill program and I worry that I won't be taken seriously.
I also don't like that more and more programs are becoming doctorates, If I wanted to be called doctor in a clinical setting I would have gone to medical school and if you truly need doctorate level preparation to be a competent provider the argument for NP degrees kind of collapses.
One of my instructors told us about the time that she went to check the capillary refill on an elderly diabetic man's toe and it just came off in her hand.

This is why all of the decent looking engineering majors at my school end up with nursing majors.
It makes sense, both are challenging but skills based science degrees that will allow you to get a decent paying job in the field with just a bachelors.

I'm cool with blood, puke, poop, pee and all of the super gross fluids but even hearing about sputum/snot or spit makes me gaggy.
I would honestly rather clean up vomit than wipe a kids drippy nose or do oral care.
Honestly that one never bothered me because it was almost always dorky, well meaning dad types who were otherwise friendlier and more polite than the average customer.
I never liked Samantha; I don't know if its because she was the doll that all of the mean girls but she just seemed bratty and condescending to 7 year old me.

I really like my Littmann Classic III; it's versatile, not crazy expensive and it comes in some pretty rad colors (mine has obnoxious highlighter yellow/green tubing). Honestly I don't see the point of investing in a super expensive cardiology stethoscope as a student, most of the people I know who have them got them as gifts from over enthusiastic grandparents.
I'm anorexic and celiac so this thread is making me even more paranoid than I already am...

I had a really bad week dealing with my eating disorder; I was honest with my therapist about how I was doing on Wednesday and she tried to send me to the ER but luckily my doctor was in the clinic was able to check me out and let me go home since we I had an appointment with her the next day.
On Thursday I got a very specific meal plan that I need to follow until my appointments next week and while I know that it is completely reasonable I'm struggling. I did ok eating yesterday, but I ended up purging at night and today I let myself sleep through breakfast, skipped lunch and really struggled through my afternoon snack and dinner.
ITS SO FRUSTRATING because I can't be hospitalized right now and I know my treatment team is amazing for letting me do this on my own but I don't know how I'm going to make myself do this every day because I'm still pretty in denial about how bad things are because I think that I look fine and my labs were normal on Thursday (which doesn't mean much). NORMAL HEALTHY COLLEGE AGED PEOPLE DON'T GET DIZZY IF THEY WALK TO FAST STAND UP SUDDENLY OR HAVE KETONES IN THEIR URINE. love science; I believe in science but for some reason it doesn't seem to apply to me and it makes me angry that I am such a hypocrite.
I know this probably isn't the sub for this but I needed to rant and y'all are smart, logical people who can maybe be rational with me.

Exactly! I have anorexia (but I also purge) and was almost hospitalized this week due to my weight and excessive purging but my labs were all still in the range of normal even though I was having wacky vitals and felt like crap.
Normal labs don't mean you are healthy, they just mean you don't need to go to the emergency room right this very second!

Well my hobbies are ballet and singing (i'm a classical vocalist) so I have a drawer in my dresser for my dance stuff, my shoes stay in my bag (and I limit myself to 2 pairs of pointe shoes at a time so I don't have a million lying around).
I do have A LOT of sheet music, anthology books and scripts from shows that I have done, but I've started getting most of my music on my iPad so I'm not too worried about that stuff getting out of control.

As someone with an eating the cereal itself might not be the problem; it could be the fact that she was expecting pancakes and got cereal which could be distressing if she had mentally prepared herself to eat pancakes.

My program makes us take our exams on this computer program that doesn't allow you to backtrack AND you get your raw score as soon as you finish.
It's the worst.
As a stress puker, I relate to this so hard.

I'm in a similar boat (anorexia b/p subtype; emphasis on the p) and today I came clean to my doctor, therapist and dietician about how poorly I've been doing.
It was hard and I still regret it because I'm terrified of gaining weight, but I'm even more terrified of dying in my 20's and not getting to live the life that I have worked so hard to create.
PM me if you ever want to talk.
Anorexia b/p subtype here, glad someone else shares my complicated relationship with vomit!
Even if this girl DID have an eating disorder, pushing food on her and putting her on the spot is probably one of the least supportive or helpful thing that I person could do.

Same! For me genitals/gender are entirely secondary, I can't imagine being like "well, you're perfect for me in every way but I can't be attracted to you because you have the wrong combination of chromosomes"
I grew up eating Nutella and yeah its tasty but I will never understand why people are so obsessed with it as there is really nothing special about it, its just another mediocre chocolate product.

Same.
I'm so scared that I am going to die if I keep this up but at the same time I am absolutely petrified of gaining weight and I quite honestly don't think that there is any medical need for it.

I want to do chicken, salmon and vegan (I figure it covers the vegetarians, dairy/egg allergies, Kosher and actual vegans).
I have celiac disease so I want to only serve gluten free food since its my day and I want to be able to eat everything gosh darn it!
I recently saw someone walking a Great Dane and a Yorkie and I almost started crying because it made me so happy.
Some people with GI problems can't handle a ton of fiber and can only eat really limited amounts of raw produce but I have a feeling that isn't what she is talking about.

I haven't been able to run (or do any cardio) in weeks because my vitals are unstable due to my eating disorder. I've been lifting and going to ballet twice a week so I'm getting in some motion but I'm so nervous about how out of shape I'll be once I can run again.
I guess I'm just scared that I'll get used to being lazy and never get back into it because building endurance sucks and I know I will get frustrated with myself.

Plus, he has interesting things going on around him. Even if you aren't into the plot, Mad Men is a visually stunning show and Don's negative traits are part of a larger more complex narrative.
The show isn't about him being a jerk, the show is about advertising in the 60's and he happens to be a jerk if that makes sense.

And, its completely possible to be a conventionally attractive socially outcast weirdo. I know how to dress myself and do my makeup but I suck at interacting with other humans, grew up being bullied and still struggle to make friends as an adult.

A lot of my favorite characters are horrible people (I love Mad Men, House of Cards and Its Always Sunny) but Girls bothers me because it is somehow both incredibly boring and rage inducing at the same time.
